Column Comment.0: STRAT NAME SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the stratigraphic name set. Astratigraphic name set is an unordered collection of stratigraphic units, that may be inuse for a Lexicon, a geographic area, a project, a company etc.
Column Comment.1: STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the stratigraphic unit.
Column Comment.2: STRAT NAME SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the stratigraphic name set. Astratigraphic name set is an unordered collection of stratigraphic units, that may be inuse for a Lexicon, a geographic area, a project, a company etc.
Column Comment.3: STRATIGRAPHIC UNIT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the stratigraphic unit.
Column Comment.4: HIERARCHY IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the hierarchy
Column Comment.5: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.6: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.7: AREA ID: Unique identifier for any named area
Column Comment.8: AREA TYPE: The type of area described, such as country, province, basin, project,business area etc.
Column Comment.9: INTERPRETATION IDENTIFIER: added to enable a single strat unit to be identifiedmore than once as part of a stratigraphic column. Multiple occurances may occur formany reasons, including folding, faulting or a non-vertical interpretationof the stratcolumn.
Column Comment.10: STRATIGRAPHIC COLUMN NAME: The name assigned to the stratigraphic column.
Column Comment.11: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.12: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date that the heirarchical relationship became effective.
Column Comment.13: EXPIRY DATE: the date on which this row of data is no longer in effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.14: INTERPRETATION IDENTIFIER: added to enable a single strat unit to be identifiedmore than once as part of a stratigraphic column. Multiple occurances may occur formany reasons, including folding, faulting or a non-vertical interpretationof the stratcolumn.
Column Comment.15: STRATIGRAPHIC COLUMN NAME: The name assigned to the stratigraphic column.
Column Comment.16: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.17: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.18: PREFERRED HIERARCHY INDICATOR: a yes / no flag indicating that thisrelationship is part of the preferred hierarchy.
Column Comment.19: REMARK: narrative remarks about the stratigraphic hierarchy relationship.
Column Comment.20: SOURCE DOCUMENT: A list of documents that are used as the source for supplyingdata. Source documents may include government and regulatory forms, operatorreports or scout tickets, publications, news letters, books or jounals.
Column Comment.21: STRATIGRAPHIC HIERARCHY TYPE: The type of hierarchy that is defined, such asbiostratigraphic (Era, Period, Series...) lithostratigraphic etc.
Column Comment.22: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.24: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.26: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
